Reviews.Title: Clear image convenient network attached camera at reasonable price
Reviews.Author: Y. Xu
Reviews.Content: I bought DCS910 in Nov.2008 and DCS920 one month later. I am quite satisfied with both of them and I did not meet any problem till now, or say I could solve the problems that I have found.The network attached camera supports up to 640x480 in resolution. It is higher then lots of other network attached camera which has only 320x240. So the image quality is quite good. It has good vision in dim light. you could see image or video on your web browser. It supports both MS ActiveX and Sun Java for live video monitoring but it does NOT support sound :(You may need to install ActiveX control plug-in and Sun Java plug-in for your browser to support live video.The supplied DViewCam software also supports monitoring up to 32 cameras and you could record videos into computer hard disk. I have not used video record feture till now because it requires turning on computer and consumes too much router/switch band width. I think check from web from time to time is good enough for my needs.It support user account management, NTP time sync, DDNS name service, FTP and email deliver of photos at the frequency you defined.The device does not support SSL protocol, so your password could not be encrypted for delivery. So you could not use [...] or ftps for secured communication. But this is understandable because encryption cost too much resources for the embeded system. You could not expect too much from tiny embeded device. Anyway, normal web access and FTP upload are good enough if you do not have too much security concern.It is quite simple to access the device from within the internal/home network because you PC and the camera are in the same network segment. But if you want to access the device from external/Internet, there are some other things to take care. You need to have some basic networking concept for the setup.I have seen one user complain the tech support and blame the device to be not usable. I could understand the mensioned situation. It is not the user's fault nor the product's fault. Tech support is not wrong on what they said but they should explain clearly on the technical background and guide the user for a smooth set up. User is not network expert so it will be a little difficult for them to understand and follow the network rules.Normally, ISP will only give one dynamic IP address to a user. The IP address will change when you turn on the router or after a certain period of time. So you need to keep track to your current IP address on the WAN port of your router. This is usually done by register a DDNS service(free or paid service). Most router support DDNS auto update service and this camera also supports it but you need to set it up in your device. All the devices in your home network will share this single IP address. Network applications will monitor communication port for TCP/IP communication. Different devices in your network have different unique IP address. The IP address for a specific device is unique in the network. So if you want to access your camera through the internet in a remote location, you need to have DDNS service set; set up a internal static IP address to your camera; setup your router port forward to your camera IP address. For example, use [...] to access your camera, you need to buy(or register a free child domain name from some website) your domain name 'mydomainname.com'; register your domain name to a DDNS server(paid or free service); setup your router to auto update DDNS for your current IP address; set router to forward 9011 port request to the 80 port of the static internal IP address that you have assigned to your camera(such as 192.168.0.3 depends on the settings on your router and camera). You may need an experienced friend to help you for the setting.Even if you have set everything correctly, it not necessarily means you could watch live video in your office. You should be able to access static current image from web browser in your office but live video is another story. Normally office network is protected by firewall on gateway. Most office firewall uses proxy and only open ports for web requests and some predefined application ports and bann all other communications. The ActiveX and Java live video of this device may need dedicated port connection to open communication session but this will not be allowed by default on the proxy. So unless you know your network administrator and could ask them open the port for you, you will not able to access live video in office. This is not the problem of the device, it is the rule of the network security. But anyway, you could see still image of your home which is good enough.I have used my DCS910 and DCS920 for 3 months and I am quite satisfied with the device. I would like to highly recommand this device to you for its clear image, easy setup(if you understand networking in and out), and resonable price.

Reviews.Title: Works great with Macs
Reviews.Author: Simdude
Reviews.Content: I have several cameras from different vendors I use as part of a home security system. I'm using with Macs running OS X and wanted to comment on how these work with this setup.The requirements for these cameras do not list OS X as an option, but they will work once you know a few things. First, the software that comes with the cameras for setup and monitoring IS only for windows. To use to OS X I did the following:1. Connect an ethernet cable between the mac and camera and make sure your network settings are using ethernet.2. Go to your web browser and enter the address [192 dot 168 dot 0 dot 20]. This is the default address for this camera.3. Enter "admin" with no password and you are now in the camera setup page.4. I would then reset the admin password, enter any login accounts you want, set up the wireless login (works fine with Airport Extreme) and finally, I usually change the network setting on the camera to a default IP address. This is needed to make the camera easier to find. If you have a wireless setup with Airport Extreme, it is usually good to use something like 10.0.1.50. This will depend on your router settings though.Once everything is setup and saved, you can unplug the ethernet cable and power the camera off and back on again. If all went well, you should be able to see the camera on your wireless network at the address you entered.If you want to be able to record video, or trigger on motion, I would recommend a program like Evological's EvoCam. This is a nice program that works great with this camera.I have used other lowend cameras like some of the Trendnets and found the image quality and low light better with the D-Link DCS920. None of these low cost cameras will work great with very little light though so keep that in mind if you intend to monitor a dark room etc. For that, you will need something with infrared which will cost more.

Reviews.Title: A Good wifi camera solution.
Reviews.Author: Jimh615
Reviews.Content: Over the last 4 years, this is my fourth D-Link wireless Camera.  I started with the DCS-900W which was a 802.11b camera.I use the cameras to watch my three dogs while I'm away.The Pros: 1.  The price is right, generally less than $100. 2.  The picture quality during daylight is good (not V.Good, nor Excellent) 3.  The speed this camera transmitts to my router is far faster than my other camera, a DCS-G900.  (The DCS-920 position replaced my G900 a 802.11g) 4.  I use the D-View Cam and like it a lot.  Rather useless unless you have at least 2 cameras or you want to record.The Cons: 1.  Digital Zoom on the DCS-920 is near useless; it gets so blurry the added digital magnification is near useless. 2.  The setup with a linksys router can be trickey and requires some serious understanding.  When I got my first one, several years ago, I called D-Link Tech Support and they were fantastic!!!  They guided me through every step.  (It was an American Tech support guy in the USA)  I have used the knowledge I gained from that setup over the years as I bought new cameras.  Have never used a D-Link router. 3.  The unit is in no way moisture proof, let alone weather proof.  It is solely for indoor use.Follow up on Sep 25, 2010.  This camera is still performing flawlessly and it is still located in the same place....in my shed in the back yard as pictured.  I now, however, have switched to a D-Link router.Follow up on Dec 23, 2011.  Camera still working out of my backyard shed......continues to provide valuable info.

} } } Length:: 0:43 MinsOn the plus side, setup was straight forward and for the current "Hot Deal" price of $60 it is one of the more reasonably priced wireless cameras around.On the minus side: - The picture is... bad, a little grainy, somewhat dim, and not vary sharp. Take a look at the accompanying video for examples. - It provides very basic functionality. Manual pan/tilt (obviously), digital zoom that only makes a bad image worse. - Once you zoom in all you see is an enlargment of the center portion of the original image. There is no way to slide the picture to see what's outside the center area. That means if what you want to see wasn't in the center of the original image you're not going to see it once you zoom in. See the video for more information. - No recording. - No microphone. That means even when you're watching the live feed you don't get any sound. - Limited picture forwarding. You define a schedule (start and stop time, day(s) of the week) and the camera will send you images at fixed intervals. The sending is either via email or to an ftp server. - No motion sensing. You can't have the camera activate and transmit pictures only when there is something interesting to see. - Access to the live images from outside your home network is between you and your router. D-Link doesn't provide any external support, such as a forwarding site, to help. - My camera arrived missing a piece for the bracket. I'm sure that's a one-off and gives me a chance to see how well their customer service responds. - The live image is rendered either through ActiveX or Java. Neither worked on my iPhone. (I'm not pointing fingers at either Steve Jobs or D-Link, just saying that for whatever the reason, it doesn't work.) - The camera is pretty big. Forget about any "hidden" recordings unless you plan in hiding this camera in a pile of cameras. See the video for a more info.I gave it two stars because, like I said, if all you need is a very basic camera, can live with the poor image quality, and are aware of the other limitations then it may meet your needs. However, if you want a whole lot more camera for a little more money then you might want to take a look at the [[ASIN:BAILSMAN Masonic BL-CA Internet Security Camera]].BTW, I feel that honest, effective reviews, accompanied by detailed videos, can take the place of first-hand experiences that are often lacking in online shopping. I've always appreciated the help I've received from other reviewers and try to return the favor as best as I can. I hope you found this review helpful and the video at least entertaining. If there was anything you thought was lacking or unclear leave a comment and I'll do what I can to fix it.

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera, Poor Software
Reviews.Author: R. Modrok
Reviews.Content: I got this camera about a month ago.  Had to call D-Link to get the wireless function to work.  Once that was resolved I couldn't get the email function to work.  After calling back and forth several times between my ISP and D-Link, D-link finally decided my camera was defective.  They said I needed to call the the RMA department.  After several calls to this department I was finally able to order a replacement camera, but I had to send my defective camera back at my own expense(9.00) UPS).  I got the replacement camera this past Saturday.  Well what do you know, the email function works.  Now if i can just figure out how this stupid software works.Bottom Line:  Camera is OK.  Software is terrible.  Also, not impressed with D-Link service...Long waits on the phone, technician hung up on me twice, was supposed to call me back and didn't.

Reviews.Title: Good value for a basic internet camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: The DCS-920 is toward the end of its product cycle. With replacement model already in retail stores and it is being heavily discounted with rebates, etc. I got 2 from Amazon (at slightly different prices) and one from Frys, averaging about fifty dollar each after rebates. This makes it one of the lowest price wireless internet camera one could find.This is my first IP camera so I bought one from Amazon, tested and make sure it works as advertised then bought 2 more.The good thing about being an older product is that most of the bugs and stability issues in earlier reviews are mostly gone.The camera ships with v1.04 firmware, which isn't available for download from Dlink's website. (it only has v1.03)I didn't use the setup CD at all. I did the followings:1. Plug it into my home router to get a DHCP address from it.2. Go to the router's admin web page to find out what is IP address the camera received,3. Go to the camera's admin web page with the IP address obtained from step 2 (login admin , no passowrd).Then I go through the configuration  and set up the camera to use static IP and also set up port forwarding on the router.It is up for internet viewing almost instantly. Later on I also got a free account from dyndns so there is no need to remember my routers's IP address assigned by Comcast, which may change over time. I primarily use the wired connection but also tested wireless (WPA2-PSK-AES) to make sure it works.To use motion detection and schedule video recording, it appears that you can only do so with the DView software. The included DView 2.03 is pretty raw and buggy. One trick is to go to the Dlink support site, select DCS-1130 and you can download the DView 3.0 software, which also supports DCS-920.  If you select DCS-920, only the DView 2.03 software is available for download. I had the camera for less than a week and have not had time to really use the DView 3.0, but it appears to be much better than the DView 2.03 shipped with the product.Pros:Excellent value with recent discount and rebatesGood picture qualitySetup is reasonably, not terribly easy or difficult. I didn't need any documentation for setup.Cons:Does not look attractive - The DCS-1130 looks better and seems smallerRather large - slightly bigger than a disposable film cameraCannot setup motion detection on the Camera to email/ftp - Need to use DView and keeps a computer running 24/7(scheduled ftp/email can be setup from the camera though)For a basic internet camera, the DCS-920's performance/price ratio is unbeatable.--- Update Nov. 2010 ---After having the camera for a few months, I find not being a able to set up motion detection/email alert on the camera itself is a severe limiation. Having another computer running 24/7 defeats the purpose of a self-contained internet camera with built in web server. The newer DCS-1130 has on camera motion detection and email alret, so does some low-end trendnet internet cameras that sells for less than $100. Maybe that's why DCS-920 is priced so low. It is still a cheap and decent entry level camera, but I will only give it 3 stars now.

Reviews.Title: I Love These Cameras....!!!
Reviews.Author: Jorge Millan
Reviews.Content: I have 6 of these cameras and I'm ordering 3 more today and 3 more somewhere in the future (for a total of 12). I love them, they are easy to set up and install. I had some problem with the D-View software because I have Vista 64 bit operating system and this software does not work with 64-bit operating systems so IF YOU HAVE 64-BIT OPERATING SYSTEM THE D-VIEW SOFTWARE WILL NOT WORK... However, you can still see the cameras over the internet and you can setup an FTP server on your PC and receive up to 3 images/per second/per camera which basically functions as a recording device. I use my iPhone and the "Live Cams" app to see all the cameras real-time from wherever I am. You have to know how to open ports in your router and use Dynamic DNS to make the cameras available over the internet. If help is needed, contact D-LINK support and they will help you set it up (if within 30 days of purchase for free support).Little personal story before finishing my review: Someone attempted to break into my house twice within a week. By the second time, I had the cameras up and running. Because the camera is kind-of big and with a green blinking light, this deterred the burglars who ran away when they realized they were on camera. The police came, I gave them the pictures, and 20 minutes later they had captured them.So in conclusion, these are nice cameras, with an excellent price. I recommend you guys to buy if you are patient enough to set up an FTP server or similar software. Interested? You will not regret it.

Reviews.Title: Great picture.  Awful instructions and software.
Reviews.Author: L. Freeman
Reviews.Content: I bought this IP Camera for watching my pets. It took almost 4 hours just to get it on my wireless network! The instruction booklet was useless and D-Link's website is just as bad. No information out there. I finally just figured I couldn't make it any worse and figured out that you have to push the reset button to set up the WPS. Once this was done, I figured out that if you unplug the camera from power, you have to reconnect to your computer to get it to sync back up with the wireless network. Maybe I missed something, but I am an electronics technician and this one almost stumped me.It is a great image if you can get everything working right.

Reviews.Title: Disappointed with it until I upgraded the firmware to 1.03
Reviews.Author: K. Hudson "Technical writer"
Reviews.Content: This product used to lose its connection to the network frequently, causing me to have to go connect a cable to reset. That happened often enough that I considered running a wired connection to it permanently. After upgrading the firmware on the camera to 1.03, I don't have those issues anymore.

Reviews.Title: Good picture, easy set up, good software, awful wireless range
Reviews.Author: T. Lowry "Troyus"
Reviews.Content: I bought this product because it looked both good and inexpensive. Moreover, my entire network is D-link and i've been happy with their products.I bought 2 of these with the intention of allowing better viewing of my autistic son when he said he was doing tasks like getting a drink. Now I have to shadow him to make sure he's doing what he said and it's intrusive.The product set up easily even to the encrypted wireless network and I had both cameras up and running within 5 minutes. The picture wasn't great, but good enough for me to see what my son was doing. At this point I was thrilled at my great purchase.Then I tried to set up the cameras in their intended resting spots. One spot was right above the wireless access point one floor up, less than 10 feet away. To my surprise the wireless that worked fine right next to the access point had trouble keeping a connection. The second camera was placed in the kitchen about 30 feet from the access point. It didn't have an absolutely clear line of site, but close to it. That one failed to connect at all.In both of these places my laptop and my WiFi enabled smart phone get 5 bars of coverage from my D-link router. In fact, it's in the heart of my best coverage.I tried moving the cameras a bit but to no avail. What good is a wireless caera with such poor wireless range? I didn't expect it to have fantastic range but even "poor" range would have met my meager needs.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, awful software
Reviews.Author: S. Greene
Reviews.Content: This camera was actually a joy to set up and has been working well for a month now.  It has great low-light performance and good picture quality.The software it ships with is another story: terrible user interface, and kept losing connection with the camera and re-establishing.  Unfortunately it appears from reviews of other products that their software isn't much better.I did find much better software out on the web: the free-demo version of LuxRiot (which I will probably eventually upgrade, but which actually works pretty well even in its free instantiation).  The LuxRiot software actually doesn't have this DCS920 listed among its supported cameras, but it does have a category that it calls "D-Link legacy," and when I configured that category it communicated with the camera brilliantly, and incidentally never loses its connection.My only wish on the camera hardware is that it had a wider-angle lens, to cover more area.  I don't know why there aren't any good inexpensive wide-angle choices.  For home security (which is my application) a little distortion would be ok, in exchange for covering more of the room.

Reviews.Title: Obsolete
Reviews.Author: 2TC
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera hoping to have some sort of motion notification, or recording. The camera build quality is good. The firmware/software, however, is outdated and worthless. The software does not work on Windows Vista/7. Additionally, neither the on-the-cam firmware nor the software supports secured E-mail connections (manditory anymore with almost all ISPs.) Find something different.

Reviews.Title: Best of its kind/price, but not excellent
Reviews.Author: lcm
Reviews.Content: The web-based config. interface is very basic, and does not readily allow one to keep local archives of images easily (there is an option to email a photo as well as upload it to one FTP server).  It does not do on-screen captions and time stamps out-of-the-box.I am using the DCS-920 as a Webcam on wunderground.com and its internal FTP client seems to be unreliable when set to the Weather Underground FTP server.  I did not experience problems with any other FTP server so I can only imagine it is some incompatibility but it is worth noting. If you plan to use this on the Weather Underground system you will need to have your computer do the uploading with a program like EvoCam on the Mac.The wireless 802.11g range is excellent compared to other models I have tried.  While it is not robust enough for mission critical applications it is a decent affordable option.

Reviews.Title: GREAT CAMERA!!!  Needs Better Software!
Reviews.Author: Mr. KnowItAll "The DVD GURU"
Reviews.Content: This is a GREAT CAMERA!!!!One drawback though....the D-ViewCam software that comes with it SUCKS!!!!!  I can't believe that only one person out of 60 reviews mentioned BLUE IRIS SOFTWARE!  This program is AWESOME, and it works flawlessly with this camera.  If you buy this camera (and I HIGHLY reccomend it), throw the included D-ViewCam software in the trash and go to blueirissoftware.com to get the best viewing/recording program that I have found for this camera.You will thank me later!Now if I can just figure out how to view the video on a computer (or phone such as the Droid X) while away from home I will be very happy.  :-)

Reviews.Title: Works well.
Reviews.Author: B.B.
Reviews.Content: Works well. Arrived quickly. This is the second one we have purchased. It isn't fancy, but it does what we expected.

Reviews.Title: For home surveilance
Reviews.Author: Jim in Colorado
Reviews.Content: I purchased two D-link wireless cameras for home surveillance.  Both cameras work perfectly.  The cameras can email pictures or ftp them.  The scheduling feature is nice, in that you can easily control how often you receive an email picture from each camera (e.g., once every hour).  If you wish to access the camera live from outside your home LAN, you need a good deal of tech savvy to set it up.  You will need to properly configure your router (assuming your router has all the necessary functionality embedded in it) and set up a dynamic DNS.  This required some background work, but once set up, it works beautifully. From any browser, I can receive live pictures and reconfigure the cameras' settings if desired.  I suspect I may have benefited from owning a D-link router -- one would think that a manufacturer would pair its products to work together nicely. If you don't mind sweat equity, this is a very inexpensive way of setting up your own home surveillance system.One feature I don't have that I might add, is a motion detector for real-time home intrusion alert.  I also wanted to monitor the internal temperature of the home, I did that by hanging a bold face outdoor thermometer ($6.00) on the wall (where a picture would normally reside) within the view of the camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Network Video Camera
Reviews.Author: James E. Livingston
Reviews.Content: I purchased one of these DLink DCS-920's from an Amazon seller.  When it was received, it was non-operational.  I contacted DLink Customer Support, and received full and complete satisfaction.  I mailed the DOA camera to DLink, and they sent me a brand new one.The camera works exceptionally well.  It has 640x480 resolution which gives very good quality picture.  The software that comes with the camera works, but not as good as it should.For under $100, this is a good item.  You will have to spend $250 or more (per camera) to get better quality.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: YM94116 "ym94116"
Reviews.Content: I have two of these and use a lot of the advanced features of this netcam.- The dynamic dns function to view live pics over the Internet- The ftp function to snapshot images to my DLink DNS-321 1TB NAS device- enabling port forwarding to enable Internet viewing- setting up a static IP address rather than using DHCP over the home router- guest accounts so others can view the pics without admin functionsOther cool features include being able to flip the image upside down or right-to-left so that you have flexibility on how you mount the camera.BTW, I like to use the term netcam to describe this because these are not webcams in the sense that they do not need to be connected to computers.  The DCS-920 works well with both PCs and Macs and works well in both a wireless-g and a wired network.  The wired method is also very helpful in setting up static IP addresses.The email function doesn't work for me as well. Ideally, I would send snapshots using gmail or Yahoo mail but the email settings do not provide enough of the advanced security settings these email services require in order to send mail through their servers.I had the old DCS-900W and I think DLink has made 5 giant leaps forward with the DCS-920.  One thing that hasn't changed for the better is documentation and troubleshooting help or manuals.  Setting up dynamic dns, ftp and email and other settings, the manual does not provide a wide range of possible configurations.Overall, the user of the DCS-920 should have a medium to high proficiency level of computer literacy since the online help won't be very useful and I hear DLink support service sucks.  I would buy these all over again!

Reviews.Title: Dont bother, pay more for a good camera
Reviews.Author: Jim Bone
Reviews.Content: I couldnt get this camera to work wirelessly unless I left my WiFi network completely open. It does not support WPA2-PSK security despite that being an option on the setup screen. I wasted almost 2 hours on tech support and the call was dropped EIGHT TIMES (I am not exaggerating). Finally the tech told me I needed to change my router security to WEP.  I basically told him to stuff it as I have 12 wireless devices on my network and if their product doesnt support a security protocol as it claims to, why should I change every other device on my network. Ridiculous

Reviews.Title: nice camera for the price, but some setbacks
Reviews.Author: Laorquidia
Reviews.Content: This camera may or may not be right for you - depending on how you want to access the camera.  It has a lot of useful features, but it comes with a lot of "buts".Pros: 1. the camera was easy to set up w/in the home network.  you can easily access it from any other device connected to the same router.2. you can access it from the internet - as long as the port you opened for the camera doesn't get blocked. (my company has port blocking - so I can not see the camera at work - which sucks.)3.  the ftp function works - so you can upload pictures to an ftp server (I upload to my website's server) and view the pictures that way.4. the motion detection works - and it will record, however, since the email does not work with smtp servers that require a secure connection - then it won't send you a message that the motion was activated.  In D-viewcam there is no FTP option - which would be nice - since the ftp does work.cons: 1. you can not access the camera from Safari in the iphone.  For whatever reason Steve Jobs doesn't allow java on Safari on the iphone (Safari on the mac has no problem accessing the camera's live feed) and this means that you can not access the live-view of your camera - unless you buy an app.  I'm trying to see if I can come up with a solution (w/o buying an app). If anyone knows how to code this - please let me know.2. if you have email that uses a secure connection - you can not email the pictures to yourself.3. the camera does have to be plugged in to work - so you don't have total freedom as to where you locate it.The camera was under $100 - so no complain about the price.  I haven't tried the ddns - so I can't comment on that.  I'm still trying to see if can work around the iphone issue w/o buying an app - if I do then i would probably give it 4*s...good luck with your security camera needs.

Reviews.Title: DCS-920 randomly disconnects
Reviews.Author: M. Jones "mj"
Reviews.Content: Accessing this model camera directly via the internet, it delivers a decent picture for this price point.  However, at the same time it routinely drops to (can't connect) status when using D-View Cam software.  After being added to the D-View Cam software camera list, it may work for an hour or even a day or so and then seemingly randomly drops off.  I have tried rebooting routers at both ends and cameras as well. The cameras still show in the D-View Cam list, but can only become connected again if you delete the camera and re-add it.  I am using a D-link router and have two of these cameras.  One is wired directly to an ethernet port on the router and the other is wireless.  They behave the same.  This has happened with both Vista (32bit) and Windows 7 (32bit).  Have pursued this through D-link dupport and my experiences are the same as many of the other folks here.  Because of this unrelable behavior and inadequate support, I can not recommend this item or D-link in general.

Reviews.Title: Satisfied
Reviews.Author: kkt
Reviews.Content: Configuration was straight forward, I accessed the camera directly using its internal webserver.  Once done, I updated the firmware and the camera worked fine.What was challening was configuring the camera for viewing over the web.  I'm using a Linksys WRT-150n router with dd-wrt firmware.  To view over the web, I had to open the camera to the DMZ.  Port forwarding did not seem to work no matter what port was opened.  This presents a future problem if I want to run multiple cameras.I only use this camera to view video over the web through IE.  I am not using the included software at all.  As such, I would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Works but bad value for the money
Reviews.Author: Kai C. Pradel "KCP"
Reviews.Content: Summary:I recently purchased two of these for use with SecuritySpy (Mac Software). I have since had the chance to test a few other cameras and found that while the D-Link camera works ok, the small image size (320x240 at 30fps) as well as spotty wi-fi make it inferior to the Linksys WVC54GCA which retails for about 20% more.Installation:- I remember that it was a bit of a challenge to get the camera to work at first, but that was mostly because I use Macs and the install disc is Windows only. I managed to get each camera up in about 10 minutes and haven't had to touch the configuration since. I suggest you set each camera up to use a static IP address (the configuration program makes that pretty simple) so in case of a restart you don't have to try to find the device again on the network.Operation:There's really not much to it. It comes with a white wall-mount that converts to a table stand. The camera itself has an annoyingly bright green LED that blinks constantly. My other test cameras came with bright LED's as well which I can only assume relieves the manufacturer from any liabilities that may come with the territory (security cameras). The lens focus ring is unintuitive as it turns endlessly in one direction and it's tough to focus. Again a downside I found other cameras share. The case is surprisingly big and bulky doesn't really "blend" in anywhere. I plan on taking mine apart to see if I can save some space or mount the camera better.The biggest issue is that the cameras tend to disconnect from the network. I think the issue is related to the fact that the cameras don't renew IP addresses when the router restarts or terminates the IP lease. That's a huge problem because the particular router I am using forces IP's to expire every 24 hours. After assigning IP's the problems only appeared every 2-3 days but still annoying (my Linksys has been running steadily for 2 weeks).Pros:- Inexpensive wireles camera- Looks like a baby monitorCons:- Small image (320x240) at 30 frames per second- No microphone- Bulky- Focusing is difficult- Annoying blinking LED in front of camera- Spotty Wi-FiGo with the Linksys wireelesss camera. It has a higher resolution, comes with a mic and has a built-in web server so you don't need any other software for monitoring.

Reviews.Title: Does not work with 64 bit machines period.
Reviews.Author: sportbikerr1
Reviews.Content: So I got this for my Windows Home Server thinking the D-ViewCam software would be great.  However heres the kicker.  Even though I was able to install this on my home server I can't view it from any 64 bit machine!!!!  The view / confiure software only supports 32 bit and crashes on 64.  I tried uninstalling the software on windows 7(x64) and it just locks up!  Time for a system recovery.I can't believe that they won't support RUNNING on 64 bit.  Come on you can make a 32 bit app that runs.  The majority of machines are now coming with 64 bit to support 4gb... Don't buy this product or ANY D-ViewCam's!

Reviews.Title: Good camera. Packaged software junk!
Reviews.Author: E. Trigg
Reviews.Content: The camera is good but the software that comes with it is virtually useless. Plan on spending another $50 for software that works.

Reviews.Title: Love these
Reviews.Author: Natasha
Reviews.Content: I have been using these cameras for a while now.  They are easy to set up and I can view them from virtually anywhere using my smart phone.  I only wish they had night vision and panoramic zoom.  Time for me to upgrade.

Reviews.Title: If you know what your doing this is a great camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Clear and works awesome with zoneminder if you need motion detection/recording. For the price and clarity you cant beat this for indoor use.

Reviews.Title: bad camera
Reviews.Author: juju58
Reviews.Content: I have windows 7 and even though it says its compatible I was not able to get it to work on my windows 7 computer or my windows xp either so I think it is a defective network camera and now I am stuck with it and cant do anything with it. it sucks!!

Reviews.Title: Not a user friendly device
Reviews.Author: Michael E. Adamson
Reviews.Content: I purchased the unit with the expectation that it would be easy to setup.  Also, if the you have a temp power failure the unit has trouble connecting back to the network.

Reviews.Title: Not good
Reviews.Author: Wes
Reviews.Content: Camera has decent resolution.Was never able to view remotely.Was never able to get it to trigger motion correctly.Was never able to keep it from losing network connectivity intermittently.I was gullible enough to order 2.And all of this AFTER speaking with tech support several times.

Reviews.Title: Good affordable camera
Reviews.Author: D. Le
Reviews.Content: Bought two of these.  Very easy to set up.  View angle is not very wide (~ 45°), but picture quality is excellent.  Quality is a lot better than the DSC-930L (I also bought two).  I did not use the software that came with the camera.  I was able to set them up so that I can use my iPhone 3GS and the IP Cam Viewer app to access my cameras remotely.  Set up was painless for me, but may require some time if you've never done IP static and port forwarding.

Reviews.Title: Convenient surveillance
Reviews.Author: PDPhotoGuy
Reviews.Content: The unit worked well with my wireless router.  It's compact.  I did need to plug it into a wall outlet.  A battery powered unit would be nice.The resolution is pretty good.  But the unit's ability to deal with contrast, particularly bright back light, is limiting.  The low light resolution is poor.  It is best to place the unit where the subject is lit from the front.  Since my problem was at night I placed a table lamp near the unit.  I got satisfactory results doing this.I found a great little software program called Vitamin D Video, online, that records movement, only, to my hard drive.  That saves a lot of hard drive space.  It can even recognize different types of movement and record only the activity you want.This is not a high end surveillance camera.  I would not use it for night security.  I would not use it to show someone entering an outside door(back light).  But it is convenient and economical for properly placed daylight use or in a well-lit room.  It served my purpose and I would buy another for the right application.

Reviews.Title: Webcam
Reviews.Author: FAVISA
Reviews.Content: Very good, the default Dview software that came with the cd didn't work.  The workaround:  download the latest Dview software from there website to be compatible with windows 7.

Reviews.Title: Not bad for the price
Reviews.Author: W. Collet "WBC"
Reviews.Content: This camera is OK for the price.Pros:Picture Quality is suprisingly goodStand is sturdyFairly easy to set up (if you have some technical knowledge)Tech Support answered the phone within 5 minutesThere is a focus dial on the front.Cons:It's not waterproof and shouldn't be used outdoorsThe wireless footage is very choppy (it becomes smooth when I plug in the ethernet cable though.  I do not recommend it as a wireless cameras)Ethernet cable is very short.Tech Support is not very knowledgeable and I called twice with different problems.  One they were able to solve, the other one they couldn't.It's Fugly looking.Direct sunlight washes out the picture.I did not use the software that came with it.  I am using it with Security Spy Software.I marginally recommend only because of the price and I would only use it hard wired.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera for the price
Reviews.Author: RandyO
Reviews.Content: Bottom line is that the thing is rock solid stable,  I use this as a simple front door monitor through my DroidX phone and IPCamView.  I can hit one button on my phone and have a live view in a couple seconds.  I also own a few of the new FosCam's with Tilt/pan and actually they are a better deal when you consider they have audio/pan/tilt capability.  The downside is that FosCam software pretty much sucks..Dlink is however more than adequate for "daytime" use and does not wash out in sunlight like many of the units I have tested.This is a DroidX screen print[...]

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, works with WPA2
Reviews.Author: J. Beck
Reviews.Content: I have used this camera every day for about a year now. It's reliable and has never become unresponsive. I am running it with WPA2 and it's a good distance from my wifi access point.Tips: Set a static IP address, you don't want to use DHCP on a remote wifi device, that's just not manageable.If you have decent working knowledge of wifi or networking, you'll be able to set this up in no time and you should have no issues. All of the negative reviews I've seen posted are from frustrated users who appear to have limited technical knowledge. I'm not bashing, but if you read the some of the reviews it becomes fairly obvious.

Reviews.Title: Works great... for awhile.
Reviews.Author: Chad
Reviews.Content: This camera worked great for about two months. Setup was difficult and frustrating, range was ok for what I needed. Purchased it because it was the least expensive cam that worked with the SKJM icam app for iphone. After about two months... nothing. Would not connect, no picture, tried troubleshooting to no avail. The picture wasn't all that great to begin with and the angle is not really wide enough to cover a room. Placed it in the top corner of a 12' wall and still didn't get the entire room. Contacting D-Link to see what they can do. Otherwise shipping back to Amazon for partial refund. Kind of a waste of time and money. Suggest doing some research before purchasing... there's better wifi camera's out there.

Reviews.Title: Good for the price
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: We've had this hooked up for about 2 weeks and love it.  We didnt install the software that came with it yet, but we realize that we need to in order to record the images.  We will eventually install the software to be able to record.  It has a great picture, even though its kinda choppy, its very clear.  The lens on the camera is adjustable, and it took us a day or two to realize that turning the lens actually makes the picture clearer.  There was nothing about this in the instructions.It would be nicer if the product ran on battery instead of having to be plugged in.  The cord is not very long, either.  But an extension cord works just fine!Had some problems with the wireless when we first tried to hook it up.  We have two wireless access points in our house, we eneded up having to rename them (they both had the same name), and stop one from broadcasting its SSID.  The camera was getting confused and didnt know which one to connect to.  Once we did this, it worked just fine.We are considering purchasing more.  Great product for the price, we got it on sale before christmas for half off.  Don't think i would pay full price for it, though.

Reviews.Title: DCS-920 is minimal
Reviews.Author: Paul Thomas Bole
Reviews.Content: I'm somewhat satisfied with this camera. It took several phone calls to tech support to get it up and running. I still cannot record images. This is not a great camera. You definitely get what you pay for.... Okay during the daytime and lousy at night... don't expect too much! ONLY BUY IF YOU RUN XP. YOu'll only need XP to setup not operate... My next IP cam will be better researched...

Reviews.Title: Great for the price
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: I have 2 of these installed in our house and have ordered 2 more.  For the price they are great.  The setup can be a little tidious and requires a bit of research to get it right.  If just used for internal viewing they are very straight forward, if you want external viewing capability youneed to have a good network understanding and be able to work with port forwarding in routers.  If you are on a normal internet connection with dynamic IPs you can use a free service like DynDNS so you don't have to keep track of your home IP address.Some other people have claimed they do not work with WPA2/PSK, this is not true as they are working on my network with that setup.  I did upgrade the firmware as soon as I got them which gives you some better options for wireless setup.  I also recomend downloading the latest software for recording the cameras.  The one that came with the cameras did not work on Windows 7.

Reviews.Title: Works great as a standalone monitoring device
Reviews.Author: Kyle
Reviews.Content: I love how you can just plug it in to A/C power and let it go free. I set mine up to auto-upload to a FTP site every 90 seconds AND host live video via dyndns. Everything was easy to set up, all you need is some basic networking knowledge. Works great with our Apple Extreme router with WPA2, and the web interface is nice.Aesthetically, the camera looks kind of funny, but it's nice how heavy the stand is, and nice how you can turn off the LED on the front so it doesn't grab attention every time I walk by. It was packaged in retail packaging, and came in another box too.Some people complain about the desktop software but I didn't have a problem since I just use the web software to configure it.

Reviews.Title: Not bad for the price
Reviews.Author: Wellcraft19 "Wellcraft19"
Reviews.Content: Not bad at all for its price. Mine has been running now for some two months, dumping an image every 30 seconds on an ftp server in the cloud.The one thing this camera lacks, is built in motion detection. If you want that, you HAVE to have the free D-Link SW running on a PC or server (like WHS) for that to work. If you can live w/o motion detection, it is not a bad camera at all.It does generate a little bit of heat, so my take is that as long as you have it sitting under an overhang, it could probably withstand the elements outside (warm enough to keep any condensation away),  - maybe bugs would eventually find it and nest inside.A final word for everyone that is touting high-end ip cams, or looking fo them: as long as we are not talking high-def video (really no ip cams match that anyway), there's no need/reason to look for a camera that supports anything else than 802.11 b/g. If you want to spend more money, look instaed for cams with better housing, optics, etc. Not more advanced radios.

Reviews.Title: Good news, bad news
Reviews.Author: GrumpyOldGeek88 "GrumpyOldGeek88"
Reviews.Content: This product does what it's supposed to do, however, it's not for the impatient user.  To set this camera up and use it to the fullest capability, you have to know/understand networking, port forwarding, DNS, SMTP e-mail, how to setup your wireless range to get the most of it, software setup, video conversion, research the web and the list goes on.  In other words, it is not really a plug and play device.My experience with this camera, I have 6 now, is as follows:My hardware (camera, router, switches) are all the same brand, D-LINK.  In my years of experience with computers and networking, using the same brand is usually the best combination when it comes to hardware "playing well together".  D-LINK in my opinion makes good products, but thier support leaves a lot to be desired, to the point it's horrible.  This is where the ability to research the internet for support comes into play.Software is another animal.  Shortly after my first camera, I upgraded to Windows 7, version 2 ofD-LINK'S software (D-ViewCAM) wouldn't even load.  However, did you know you can use your browser to monitor the camera without software? You can't record, but you can keep an eye on things from anywhere in the world. I can even view all 6 of my cameras on my Droid smartphone!I found out this past summer that D-LINK had released version 3.1 of thier software that works with Windows 7 32 or 64 bit.  After some poking around, I found it, installed it and was fairly impressed.  I know there is third party software that might do a better job and I may try it someday, but D-ViewCAM does the job for now.  I did have one bad experience with the new version of software, it gave me a BSoD (Blue Screen of Death) on my main computer if I left it running in the background to record video.  This computer is Win7 Pro, 64 bit.  Whether it's the D-ViewCAM software or something else, I don't know.  But I solved the problem by testing the software with an old laptop running Win7 Home Premium 32 bit.  It's been running for 3 months now and never a BSoD or even a reboot. This allows me to record to my server. I think it's the 64 bit OS that gave me the BSoD.Although there has been complaints about the image quality of these cameras, I think it's pretty darn good.  Personally, I'm not producing a Hollywood blockbuster, I just want to see an good image.These cameras have become a pet project of mine and I could go on and on about the good, bad and what you can and can't do with these cameras, but the bottom line is, they do the job for what they were designed to do and they're fairly cheap.

Reviews.Title: wireless camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "GCH"
Reviews.Content: The equipment works great, the software will not allow you to reduce the screen size which stinks!

Reviews.Title: Good Camera for the Money
Reviews.Author: Frequent Amazon'er
Reviews.Content: This is a fairly good camera for the money.  I am using it Ethernet Attached to the home network for monitoring the dog crates.For general use I have :- Image setup parameters as : Brightness Control +2 Contrast Control +1, all other are the factory defaults.- Video Setup parameters as : 640 x 480, 30 fps, Very High JPEG quality and view mode as Java ( using Firefox 3.6.3 ), Light Frequency as 60 Hz.In no light conditions, the image is black ( not a night image camera, so it is as advertised ).I used the CD setup to get the IP address set on the camera, and then used the web interface to the camera direct to change the image / video parameters, and disable the WiFi interface ( the DCS910 is no longer available ).The Laptop I am using to monitor the image is over 802.11a WiFi, and the traffic generated is not bad at all.I tested the image to my FTP server, and it works fine, will do upto 3 fps still images sent to the ftp server, or an auto setting ( did not try this one ). Images sent to the FTP server are ~ 55KB each.Uploaded Screen capture to the customer supplied pictures, so others could see exactly what the Web UI looked like, and the image quality.  30 fps does not sound like a lot, but it is useful for monitoring items ( not live video feed like a baby video monitor ).I was at the point of getting the summer Infant 7" baby monitor LCD screen to augment the 2" one I have ( screen too small over the long term ) and cost wise this vs the 200.00 baby monitor, cost won out, and I am glad I went this route.If you are looking for a low cost usable video security camera, this is a good one to pick.  No audio with this one, so if that is a requirement, might want to look at the other brands.

Reviews.Title: Overall a good camera for the money.
Reviews.Author: Honest John "TheThinker"
Reviews.Content: Very easy to set up. Only complaint is that the video quality could be better but for the money what can you expect?

Reviews.Title: Great Value
Reviews.Author: Gomer
Reviews.Content: D-Link DCS-920 wireless camera is a great value. They are easy to set up for wireless use and have a good picture. If you get a free account with [...] you can access them from anywhere. The d-view software is a little unstable but it does work OK. I did call tech support once and the wait was less than a minute and they were somewhat competent. I paid about 70 bucks each for these and they had a $20.00 rebate. For the price I dont see how you could go wrong. I have used other IP cameras that are pan/tilt and they were nothing but trouble. If you are looking for a cheap color wireless addition to your security system this is it.

Reviews.Title: Pretty good decent cost solution
Reviews.Author: D. Vineyard
Reviews.Content: I picked up this camera to replace an older linksys camera that had weak wireless security.  As a computer professional that matters to me.The intructions assume you use the installation software to help configure the camera.  Which wasn't as useful to me since I wanted to configure it differently on my network.  You configure it using the network cable included in the package.  You may need to disable your wireless network in order to allow you to see the camera.  If you use the software you can configure all the network settings to match that of your wireless router.  I had to power it off/on in order for the settings to seem to take hold.  I then disabled the camera network and re-enabled the wireless, connected to the Router and configured the device there with DHCP and an assigned IP address so the Router will always assign the same IP to it every time.  Then I set up the port forwarding so the router sends traffic coming in to it on to the camera at that port.  I use port 8080 since I already have other stuff running at the default http port 80.  I use DynDNS so anything coming in using the camera port, gets forwarded on to the camera.  eg. [...] brings up the camera.  That's it.  Didn't take that long to have it online.  Signal strength is much better than the old camera I was using.The image is pretty good, though the zoom is for the most part worthless.  Digital zooms are just too grainy.  Color is off, and I still need to adjust them, but that is minor for the moment.  Low light works pretty good.  Though dark is still dark.  It is not a night vision by any means. Image size is nice.  Having problems with email and ftp setup, though that is probably a security issue on my server.  Not sure yet.  Be sure to click on the save button before the Test button, or the settings don't seem to be set otherwise.One of my favorite things about the webcam is that it supports a simple image snapshot.  You can see this if you yse the page [...] instead of the default.  This is really nice as I cannot run the activex of java controls needed for video streaming on my smartphone.  But with this page I get a single snapshot image per each refresh of the page.  Nice to be able to check it from anywhere.  The image here is the same quality and everything.I'm pleased with this camera, and considering buying another one for another room in the house.  Maybe not the simplest to set up, but as easy as any I've installed.

Reviews.Title: So-so camera, but it is wireless
Reviews.Author: ZZB "zz_91125"
Reviews.Content: The camera was reasonably easy to set up, although enclosed softwarefor finding camera on the network did not work (but it was easy to findIP address of the camera on the router, and just follow the link).It is somewhat disappointing that audio is not supported.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: John R. Pattison
Reviews.Content: Great little camera!  Good picture quality and easy to configure.  I like that you can configure the video quality (useful based on what kind of connection you will be viewing it from).  I found software to view it on my Motorola Droid running Android (software is called "IP Camera Viewer") and great software to run on my computer to detect people in a defined area and notify me by email (called "Vitamin D").  Overall it makes a very inexpensive surveillance solution.

Reviews.Title: very useful
Reviews.Author: Gerald Aubertin "Jerry"
Reviews.Content: Cam was a little tricky hooking up wireless, so that I could access the cam from the web, and not have to leave computer on. Call support a couple of time very helpful. I use it mostly checking on home. It also fun to talk with Girlfriend on cell and seeing her.

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: Brian L. Morgan
Reviews.Content: Does what I need it to do and that is monitor home temperature when traveling. I place a thermometer by the camera and I can view the temperature inside the house and also its so great for piece of mind when traveling. Also it sends snap shots to an email address so I can view temperature and house security over a period of time. Also for piece of mind I can see that no one has broken into the house.

Reviews.Title: Works Great
Reviews.Author: John K
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to be able to view my home remotely, It took a while if i may add but it worked. On a trip abroad i was able to monitor my home while thousands of miles away. Pretty cool if u ask me. The only downside is the dlink software. Somethings gotta be done about it.

Reviews.Title: Right product at this price point.
Reviews.Author: R. Tackett
Reviews.Content: The product does work as advertised.  The software that's included is all but worthless.  It appears that if you want to do something like monitor your home then you need to buy some decent software to actually manage your camera(s).  That software appears to be Blue Iris.  With it the camera works very well and does exactly what I want.  I did take some learning to figure out how this whole thing works and I wouldn't recommend any product like this for someone who isn't technical.  It does do what I want however and the price is right for this product.  If you do your homework you'll find that if you want high quality video then you will spend double to triple the price of this camera.

Reviews.Title: Perfect for simple security cam
Reviews.Author: J. Kwok
Reviews.Content: Easy to setup and worked right out of the box. Setup through my home router to view over the internet took less then 2 minutes.  Though I'm a network admin so it's simple for me or anyone that understands the OSI model of a networking architecture.I set this up at home to monitor my front door walkway.  It doesn't move, has no sound, and is fixed with a single focal range. Great price with an additional $20 rebate from D-Link. I enjoy the basic D-Link software with the option to setup 32 cams for when the time is needed. It's probably not the best if you solely want to view it from a phone. This was not my intended purpose nor have I tested it on any type of smart phone. Again this is a great basic security cam for lan purposes. If you understand networking this would then be easy enough to setup through your router.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing video quality
Reviews.Author: John F. Ryan "ryanjo"
Reviews.Content: I own both a Linksys WVC54GCA  Wireless G Internet Camera and an older D-Link wired DCS-900 network camera, so I have some experience with setup and management of these webcams.SETUP: The procedure for setting up the DCS-920 on the network was easier than either of other two webcams I have setup, either manually or using WPS, which is supported with selected wireless routers. The setup details of remote (internet) access are very poorly documented in the manual with the product, and only slightly better in the CD "wizard". You still have to go to an internet site and setup an account for a dynamic name server, and enter the server info manually in the web-browser based camera utility. Fortunately, using the WPS setup option with a compatible wireless router, opening ports on the router is no longer a tedious trial-and -error process. Overall, setup rates a "B" grade.WIRELESS OPERATION: After setting up the DCS-920 however, I was so disappointed with the video quality that I returned the item. Although the refresh rate with either the Active-X or Java settings was acceptable, sharpness at even the lowest resolution was so poor that it wasn't possible to recognize faces. The video quality using it as a wired network camera (which isn't the point of a wireless webcam, after all) was marginally better, but still worse than my Linksys WVC54GCA used wireless. Ease of home network functioning = "A", internet webcam operation= "B+", Video quality="D".

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the price
Reviews.Author: Dale Donchin
Reviews.Content: Works well.  Good quality image.  Only negative is lack of documentation of default IP and MAC address for wired Ethernet port.

Reviews.Title: Easy and practical
Reviews.Author: R. Garcia Alvarez "The Real Mckoy"
Reviews.Content: The only downside is the image quality, it is not as sharp as I expected but it is fair enough. Nice product easy to install.

Reviews.Title: Easy to setup and good picture quality
Reviews.Author: BobN2Tech
Reviews.Content: I also own the wired version, DCS-910, but wanted a 2nd camera for my vacation house. Since I did not want to run a long CAT5 cable, this was perfect. After a bit of difficulty in setting it up for viewing over the Internet from a remote location, it works great. Since there are no instructions on how to use it via the internet, but only for LAN use, I had to call D-link for support. This time, I did get a knowledgable person who helped me set the correct router virtual server settings. Last time, with the DCS-910, I was not so lucky and the person told me I could not have Dynamic Dns, without a router that has this feature - which was not true. Very Satisfied.

Reviews.Title: excelent IP camera (cost-benefit)
Reviews.Author: jose teran "Jojo"
Reviews.Content: i bought two of this cameras and i regret not buying 2 more, they have a very good cost benefit relation

Reviews.Title: Great for the price
Reviews.Author: Clipdin
Reviews.Content: I've been researching wireless webcams for a while and was put off by most of the reviews, but this one seemed like it was worth a shot.The setup was pretty straight forward.  I also had a problem with the software recognizing the camera....it never found it, even when I typed in the IP address.  Luckily, you don't really need it.  If you just log onto it directly using a web browser and the IP address you have access to all the configuration you need.  Once you have it in place you need to focus the lens with the black ring around it and your done!I now have it set to ftp a picture every 60 seconds to my website where I can check on my house and my pets throughout the day.Great for the price!!!

Reviews.Title: Pain in the but but decent
Reviews.Author: Paul C. Skertich "Paul"
Reviews.Content: The image quality is good. I've been trying to get the D-View Cam to work. note to those - D-View cam does not work on 64 bit version of vista. So don't bother. However, I had a bit trouble the camera to be recognized so I had to manually configure it under model DCS-900 Bx. That worked. This was a upgrade version of D-View Cam 2.02. It's an okay product. I'm gonna buy something better within the D-Link family of cameras.

Reviews.Title: Pretty simple setup
Reviews.Author: Michelle Stone "litebkt"
Reviews.Content: I use it as a webcam for my observatory.  I just point it out the window from inside. I've had no major problems with it.  The setup was fairly simple. I wish that it were easier to assign it a static IP. There isn't any way to point it to a name server. So, I just let it use DHCP which most users want anyway.The instructions are a bit trite when setting up a webcam to takes a picture every few minutes. This wants to be full motion video.The included software to watch more than one of these at a time installed but could not find the camera. I tried it on a couple of computers.  You know, if I can get to it via a web browser (as in the control interface), you'd think that their software could find it.Overall, I'm happy with it. It's only been running a couple weeks, but it is doing a good job.

Reviews.Title: Product works as advertised
Reviews.Author: Jaybird
Reviews.Content: The product works mostly as advertised.  The instruction manuals are very lame, but the web interface, FTP and Email photo functions all work nicely, once you get them set up.  One note:  The camera is virtually useless at night.

Reviews.Title: Disappointing Wireless Range
Reviews.Author: J. Guevara
Reviews.Content: I bought the DCS-920 to supplement my old DLink DCS-2100+. It's easy to setup, configure &  small. I find the wirelless range to be less than half the range of my old DCS-2100+. It  worked great in wired ethernet setup but that's not the reason why I bought it. I need it  in wireless mode and it failed my expectation. I prefer not to crawl inside ceilings, drill holes and run cables, the reason why I bought a wireless ip camera.

Reviews.Title: No Win7 software support - Lame Techs
Reviews.Author: K. Kistler
Reviews.Content: Software would not work with Windows 7 (64 bit), even though compatibility claimed on the MS web site.Was wanting to use for motion detection surveillance of home while away, but their software would not complete install properly, and crashed every time attempted to run.Their tech support line was very lame, (both email and voice) would give no projected date for software compatibility or attempts to fix, only suggestion was that I return the two camera's I bought for refund.I did finally get the camera's to work by using third party (Argus) software.

Reviews.Title: D Link
Reviews.Author: hagar
Reviews.Content: I could not get this device to work, and I tried multiple computers, 2 different wireless routers and different security and firewall settings. Camera does connect to my wireless router, but it will not bring up the webpage to view it. I consider it junk.

Reviews.Title: Good for the Price
Reviews.Author: Charles
Reviews.Content: This camera is a good network camera at this price range. It was easy to setup and I thought the software that came with it was simple to understand and use. The reason I give it 3 stars is because the camera signal is very poor at around 30 feet. The signal seems to even drop at times. I have moved it closer to my access point and now it works great. I have two other wireless cameras and they appear to work well from about 30 feet. This camera has a shorter ant. could possibly replace with bigger one, but I am happy for what I gave for it. Also should point out this camera has no sound so if you need this look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: It is OK
Reviews.Author: M. A. Higgins "Markhig"
Reviews.Content: It was easy to setup and does what I need it to do, which is allow me to watch a car lot for customers from my office. I have made no attempt to access it from outside my network, so I cannot speak to that use. My biggest problem with it:  if I blow up th picture to full screen the way I like it, the picture quality is very poor. If I keep the picture small, it is a good picture. But even when the picture quality is bad, on the full screen, I can see if a customer comes so it works for me and was inexpensve.

Reviews.Title: Returned, very poor Technical Support
Reviews.Author: Alfred Heyer "Mac man"
Reviews.Content: After many frustrating hours trying to get to work with my Mac finally gave up and returned.D-link's Technical Support is horrible.  It takes 24 hours or more to get a chat response and whoever is on the other end doesn't speak English very well, doesn't appear to comprehend or read questions completely, or incorporate info providing in earlier responses (ie treats each question like a brand new one!).To Amazon's credit, their Return process work smoothly and I received full credit in a timely fashion.

Reviews.Title: the camera is ok (for the price); but poor customer service & tech support
Reviews.Author: C. Wu "foreverjimmy"
Reviews.Content: the customer service AND tech support both never give straight answer to any of my questions; other than transfering me fwd, or offering me NEW phone number to call.will never buy d-link product again!

Reviews.Title: Not compatible with my wireless router encryption, and $20 rebate never came
Reviews.Author: grayzhu
Reviews.Content: This device did not work with the ATT 2wire DSL wireless router. After a lot of experimenting, I found I had to change my wireless router encryption to WEP to work with this device, none of the other encryption would work. Most folks would have given up and returned, but I thought with $20 rebate each, it may be worth keeping them (I bought two around Xmas time 2009 right here). However, I am disappointed the rebate never came after I sent them everything required (cut the bar code, receipt, and the rebate form etc) near the end of January.  Never a communication about this rebate.

Reviews.Title: Not bad for a starter camera.
Reviews.Author: A. Cox
Reviews.Content: First, be warned... do not try Dlink on-line support.  The don't reply.  Use the call-in number (to India).  If you are able to get the camera working, the picture quality is pretty good.  The low light conditions could be better. The DCS920 has inconsistent fps results.  Sometimes I get 30fps, other times it gets less than 1 fps.  I am using a dlink wireless router, so they should have optimal compatibility.  The nice thing about this camera is in the manual setup mode (web based), there is a copy-paste code that makes it easy to broadcast on your website.  I do not care for the d-link view software that was included. It's not always easy to get it to acknoledge the existence of the camera.

Reviews.Title: Poor Camera
Reviews.Author: J.D.
Reviews.Content: No support and instructions were terrible. I would not buy this product. I bought 4 cameras and sent 3 of them back because I couldn't get the first one to work at all no matter what I tried.

Reviews.Title: Works fine for a cheap cam.
Reviews.Author: Diego
Reviews.Content: Pros: Good for indoors and in environments with good illumination.Cons: Software that comes with it ...SUCKSSSSS!!! Use Vitamin D ... runs in Mac & PC

Reviews.Title: Not very recommended
Reviews.Author: A. Leonard
Reviews.Content: [...] Set-up for this cam, although seemingly simple, it's not. For some reasons certain selections can't be made (eg 24/7 economic rec - motion sensing). Why? Three of us have been racking our brains. All the system reg are met. But the dam configuration wizard will confirm our selection for 24/7 economic rec but when you reopen the wizrd the setting goes back to default. That's just one example. There's other issue. Caveat emptor. No instruction manual and the help button has no topics.

Reviews.Title: Affordable Solution
Reviews.Author: T. Jolie
Reviews.Content: I've been dabbling with a weather station for a few years now.  One thing I wanted was a web cam to go along with my station.  The problem is most solutions were not affordable.  I decided to try this camera mostly because the price was right.  Now, this is not an outdoor camera but what I did was I mounted inside looking out.  What I ended up with is a both a weather cam and a view of who is coming and going in my driveway!The camera was a bit tricky to setup.  I'm pretty technical and I have a good working knowledge of networking.  I found it very hard to get the wireless camera to see my network.  I actually gave up the night I tried to set it up.  Then the next morning it seemed to work.The camera also came with some software for managing a network of cameras.  The installation kept hanging while unpacking some .Net related cab files, complaining it was out of system resources.  My PC is about 4 years old and has seen better days.  I do have 1 GB of memory and available memory at install time seemed fine.  I gave up on that since I really don't need to manage multiple cameras.  If I ever do I have the option of installing on a different machine.I actually wrestled with FTP setup as well.  This was a new ftp site and I could easily connect to it through command line ftp.  It seems the camera software liked an IP address better that a qualified name.  I guess I can't fault the camera here as getting FTP going usually takes a few tries until you get the settings right, no matter what the software.So just be prepared to wrestle with the setup a bit.  If you have the patience and know-how for this, then I think this is a great camera for the price.

Reviews.Title: The quality is not good
Reviews.Author: P. Yu "P. Y"
Reviews.Content: The quality is not good. I have had it for 3 months then suddenly the camera stopped working properly. Called Amazon, and was told they only accept return in 1 month. Have to call D-Link, they tried all the could and admitted something was wrong with the camera. They asked me to send the camera back for repair and I have to pay the shipping by myself.Basically, I would say the quality it's not good and the software doesn't work with Windows 7.

Reviews.Title: dont buy if u have win7
Reviews.Author: David C. Satchell "unionjack"
Reviews.Content: More trouble than its worth!!!Software dosnt work in win 7 64 bit and no sign of any updates from vendor....

Reviews.Title: NOT Vista 64 compatible.  Also, software is lousy
Reviews.Author: M. Williams
Reviews.Content: I checked to see if this product was Vista 64 compatible before purchasing.  D-Link states that the software is Vista compatible.  That really isn't helpful if it is only compatible with one version of Vista.  Anyway, after several emails to tech support, I was told that the software will not work with Vista 64.  I do have a Windows Vista 32 computer as well and installed the software on it.  The software is very basic and worthless as far as I'm concerned.  I ended up purchasing two web cams and stand alone security software and am much happier.  I now have two web cameras and software for less than the D-Link DCS-910 costs.  The DCS-910 does make a good, yet expensive paper weight.

Reviews.Title: Software Dosent Work-What use is this?
Reviews.Author: C. Men "Tech Geek"
Reviews.Content: Ok, I bought this D-link IP Camera, in hopes of putting it on my family room.Once I got the package, I opened it and found the camera, cat5e network cable, stand, mounking kits, and the software. I got out my laptop and installed the Wizard that is supposed to setup your camera to work on the network.That was OK. I could see myself locally (IP Adress)Then, I installed the D-View Cam software, whitch is supposed to give me DVR recording capabillites and view up to 16 cams at a time. When I tried to add the first camera to D-View Cam, It could not find the camera in Atuo and Manual camera discovery modes.I am very dissappointed with the quality of a product from a reputable company such as D-Link. I am returing this product tommorow.

Reviews.Title: Poor software and firmware
Reviews.Author: A. Jackson
Reviews.Content: SummaryNot recommended.  Buy a Linksys instead.  Expected more from a company like D-Link.PROSThe firmware interface is fairly straight forward.CONSCannot set image qualityD-ViewCam software does not work with Windows 7/64 with noDoes not support firmware motion detection and capture.  Must use D-ViewCam software instead.

Reviews.Title: D-Link Internet Camera
Reviews.Author: Craig Sandel
Reviews.Content: I am a high medium techy when it comes to making things work. After spending hours trying to set up this "easy to set-up" camera, I called the help desk and was told the problem was with my cable modem port settings.  The cable company rolled a truck and came out to find no problem.  I called for an RMA and got another tech, who told me totally different story.  I finally got a picture, but found it's size and resolution made it pretty unusable for my purpose.  Bottom line is "you get what you pay for" I guess. I cut my losses and Amazon graciously took the product back.

Reviews.Title: No luck with internet viewing
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I got this internet camera to watch my house from internet. It is really easy to set up the camera to view it within the wifi system. However, viewing from internet is a totally different story. I have Verizon Fios as internet provider with MI-424-WR router. Called D-Link support line and they don't want to touch Verizon router (maybe don't know either). Called Verizon support, only pointing to a port forwarding site for reference. Even used paid service for wifi router set up. All the things tries are: port forwarding, firewall rule management, putting the camera in a DMZ area, etc. Long story short, I am going to return the camera. Thought my self as tech savvy, done quite wifi networks at home, setting up servers for my own computer. Buyer beware.

Reviews.Title: Life is too short - a waste of time and money
Reviews.Author: A.I.R. "A.I.R."
Reviews.Content: First  - I am a credible writer - and quite computer literate (consulting for others).The bottom line - the camera performed only 1 function in a modestly acceptable manner - it permitted me to view the image from the internet. Yes - it was better priced than competing products and offered free website access - both positive attributes.Second - Now  - where the camera (and Dlink Tech Support / Customer Service) failed after hour upon hour of working with Dlink Tech support:a. The camera did NOT send emails via their software - therefore NOT as advertised.b. The camera's software did NOT recognize the cameras - therefore NOT advertised.c. I was therefore unable to record key images and video - therefore NOT as advertised.d. Their tech support was grossly inadequate and ill-prepared to help.e. I wasted almost 7 hours with techs, writing emails, getting disconnected and reconnecting several times after being placed on hold for extended periods of time - and ultimately given bad advice and guidance - all of which left the problems unresolved.f. One tech finally admitted that even THEY have trouble getting the software to work properly with the cameras - and REGULARLY see these problems. While he was the most polite and responsive - he could not solve the problems either.g. They do not read the details of emails I sent requesting help - rather - they respond with canned, useless verbiage.h. I cannot use the cameras as advertised.One of the worst recent experiences with any product I purchased.Just a shame.(All my opinion - do your homework and form your own.)
